James E. Ball, an art teacher and coach at North Point High School, is a finalist for the Maryland Teacher of the Year Program.

Ball supports students’ health and learning through art exploration, education, and experimentation. He earned both a master’s degree in education and a bachelor’s degree in studio art from West Virginia Wesleyan College.

The cornerstone of Ball’s art pedagogy is digital journaling which he shares with his students. Ball coaches cross-country, basketball and girls lacrosse.

Each summer, he runs basketball clinics for students with special needs and teaches art appreciation through the Charles County Sheriff’s Youth Achievement Camp. He also leads a variety of basketball skill-enhancement sessions.

The 2020-2021 Maryland Teacher of the Year will be announced on Maryland Public Television on Oct. 8 in a special program airing 8 p.m. on MPT2 and in a livestream on MPT’s Youtube.com channel MarylandPublicTV.

Dispatch from McDonough Athletic's Twitter — Members of Maurice J. McDonough High School's athletic department "spirit caravanned" to the homes of their senior athletes earlier this week. The trip was to show their appreciation for the hard work and dedication students displayed before their sports were sidelined due to the school closure. The kids were given softballs, baseballs and lacrosse balls with the school logo.

The note given to the students read: "Dear Senior Athlete, You have been 'spirit caravanned!" We want you to know that we appreciate all that you did preparing yourself for the season. We are sad that your senior year is being cut short of all of the important rites of passage that you all should be experiencing. We want you to know that what you have given to the McDonough Athletic Department has not gone unnoticed. Years from now when you look back to your high school years, remember your time on the field or track and know you were appreciated."

Charles County Public Schools (CCPS) physical education and health teachers recently participated in an OmmWorks training. Earlier this year, OmmWorks led a training during an in-service day to guide CCPS staff through meditation, mindfulness and basic yoga. The training can be incorporated into CCPS PE curriculum to help students relieve stress.

The training included information about the seven energy systems and internal connection between physical, emotional, psychological and energetic components that play a key role in the body's vital energy and overall health, Michelle Ignaszewski, adapted PE teacher, said.

The participants were given a training manual and guidebooks that can use to empower students to self-regulate emotions and reach their full potential, she said.

John-Michael Keyes, co-founder of The "I Love U Guys" Foundation, visited Charles County from Colorado this week to talk with more than 50 school safety representatives about response protocols and reunification methods. Keyes’s daughter, Emily, was killed in 2006 by a gunman who took her Platte Cannon High School classroom hostage. Keyes and his wife, Ellen, founded I Love U Guys — named for the last text Emily sent to her parents — to aid in strengthening school and community safety, and family reunification after a crisis.

Charles County Public Schools (CCPS) office of school safety and security, and the Maryland Center for School Safety hosted Keyes at the Starkey building.

CCPS uses the I Love U Guys Foundation’s standard response protocols and works with local law enforcement to continue updating practices and training to ensure CCPS is a safe place for teaching and learning.

To read more about response codes used by CCPS, go to https://tinyurl.com/vazjs6u.

Once a week, students at Dr. Gustavus Brown Elementary School meet to talk. They chat about animals, colors and say the Pledge of Allegiance without making a peep. The sign language club at Dr. Brown has been meeting for three years under the direction of Darcy Piazza, an educational sign language interpreter with Charles County Public Schools (CCPS).

Many students joined the club to better communicate with their friends who are deaf or hard of hearing. “I knew there were deaf people in my school, and I knew I wanted to talk to them,” said Olivia Bellamy, a fifth grader who has been in the club for three years. She also wanted to be able to help others communicate by acting as an interpreter.

To read more, go to https://tinyurl.com/uoptqfp.

Schools coordinate a variety of job shadow activities for students, ranging from guest speakers and career fairs, to working with community partners to build support for career partnerships. Students also participate in on-the-job training experiences.

Thanks to Charles County Government for sharing these pictures of our students!

This afternoon — disguised as the Berry Jaguer — he surprised his younger brother, Rahsaan, a Berry Elementary School fifth grader. “To be able to come here and surprise him after all this time is amazing,” Bass said. Then, they headed to Theodore G. Davis Middle School so Bass could surprise his sister, Sasha, who is in seventh grade. “I said there is no way he would be here,” Sasha said. “And then, he just was.”

News crews from NBC4 and Fox5 were there to capture the reunions. To see the stories, tune into NBC4 tonight at 5:45 and 6:45 p.m. The piece is set to air on Fox5 at 4, 5 and 6 p.m. tonight.

North Point High School welcomed members of the Lesole's Dance Project last week for a Black History Month presentation held during NEST, the school’s one-hour lunch.

Founded in 2003 by Lesole Z. Maine, a native of South Africa, the dance company conducts classes and workshops around the metropolitan area immersing audiences in Southern African culture. In addition to performing traditional dances, the company is known for its American modern and Afrofusion dance performances, and Juneteenth celebration.

Among the dances shared with North Point students — who were invited to participate — was the gumboot dance performed by dancers in bell-adorned wellington boots. The dance originated in the tunnels of gold mines in South Africa as a form of communication among the miners.

School staff advised parents of car riders of the power issue this morning as they arrived to school, and asked several parents to take their children home if they were able to.

Bus riders and student walkers are in the school cafeteria. The power outage is affecting the Carrington neighborhood where Dr. Brown is located.

Charles County Public Schools (CCPS) does not have an estimate from SMECO at this time as to when the power will be restored.

As a result of the outage, the school's phone system has intermittent service.
